awd_titl_txt: NSFDEB-NERC: Collaborative Research: Informing population models with evolutionary theory to infer species' conservation status
awd_abstract_narration:
Marine species are very hard to census. This is especially true of large, high value fishes that are vulnerable to overfishing because of their biology. For example, one third of shark and ray species are known to have declined in recent history, but it is unknown whether most of the remaining two-thirds are also declining, or if they are stable. Likewise, population sizes of predatory fishes such as groupers and tuna have decreased substantially due to intense fishing, yet little is known about the extent of decline and risk of extinction for some of these species. This project uses the evolutionary history of well-studied related species to provide estimates of basic demographic properties of little-studied species of fisheries and conservation importance. This knowledge provides important information to guide management efforts, such as limits on catch and trade, until more direct research can be carried out. The researchers will also engage in educational outreach on mathematical biology for undergraduates and on marine biodiversity science for the general public. 

Scientists often have some knowledge of individual traits such as reproductive behavior, lifespan, and metabolic rates of many related fish species, even in the absence of population-level information. Evolutionary theory can predict the co-evolution of these unique trait combinations of various groups. This theory can be used to infer demographic rates and project species' status, but previous efforts have not incorporated the unique details of each species' biology. This project will develop comprehensive theory linking the evolution of these traits to species status projections for tunas, groupers, and sharks and rays. Modern statistical methods will allow information from models of data-rich species, which have formal assessments, to be shared with poorly studied species in similar habitats, or with relatives. With this new understanding of population trajectories, the team will produce recommendations for use by organizations like the International Union for Conservation of Nature, as well as managers and scientists.

por.por_cntn:
One challenge in marine biodiversity conservation is that we frequently do not have records about the historic abundance and current status of fished species that migrate long distances or live in the tropics. Without scientifically sound criteria to prioritize management and policy, this data vacuum has led to several local extinctions and the collapse of fisheries that were once important for human nutrition and healthy ecosystem functioning. We further do not fully know how fishing and climate change will interact to affect the productivity of fished species in the future.  

 

This project addressed the fundamental gaps in knowledge about the population declines in high value fish species using models designed to leverage information about their evolutionary history in a novel way. Our objective was to create quantitative tools for assessing high-value fish species most at risk of overfishing, designed for species about which we otherwise do not have much knowledge about historical abundance and population declines. This toolset was developed to incorporate unique complexity in species' biology, such as the migrations of tunas from warm to temperate waters, live birth in many sharks and rays, and female-first sex changing behavior of groupers (wherein only the largest individuals reproduce as males).  All of these species are economically valuable in the global economy, and have historically been subject to intense fishing pressure.

 Intellectual merit: we developed a new statistical approach to merging evolutionary information on species relatedness and how natural selection has shaped the traits of these species prior to fishing to fill in missing information on traits and trends over time. The ultimate purpose of this is to provide rigorous information on overfishing status to inform trade agreements such as the Convention on International Trade of Endangered Species (CITES).  We showed that fisheries high-seas species of sharks and rays have led to their populations declining by 71%, on average. Coastal species of sharks and rays have shown similar declines in the southwestern Atlantic, but after fisheries management was enacted in the northwest Atlantic in the early 1990s, many species have recovered.

 Some high-value tuna species are well-studied and managed, but there are several related species which are understudied. A major unknown is how their spawning behavior will change as climate and oceanic food webs change.  We took advantage of the information available on well-studied tunas to develop and validate a model of fish growth and reproduction that incorporated size-based prey capture success and risk of predation. This was a novel advance in our general understanding of how cold-blooded (ectothermic) species' traits adapt to varying conditions of food richness and temperature. Contrary to previous reports that warming oceans will lead to reduced body sizes in fishes, we found that food (prey capture success) was much more important in determining the body sizes of tunas. We also predicted that the spawning output of tunas, not growth, was likely to decrease as waters eventually warm, but that this would take an extreme increase in mean water temperature (more than 5 degrees Celsius) which is outside the range of current expectations. Our analysis also produced the result that seasonality in prey availability - which will not change in the high-latitude oceans - is as important as temperature in determining how fishes, including tunas, adapt their environment.  This mechanistic theory complements our statistical analyses of the traits of tunas and sets the stage for future research addressing the interacting effects of climate and fishing pressure on seafood resources in general.

 We also investigated the sustainability of fisheries for grouper, which are high-value species that live primarily in the tropics. There are very few data on groupers, making quantitative analyses of their risk of overfishing extremely difficult. We generalized an existing framework for understanding the way that fishing affects the biology of sex-changing species and applied it to two culturally and economically valuable groupers in the tropical eastern Pacific. This approach has the potential to be applied to other data-sparse fisheries. We have archived a publicly available version of this code for anyone to use.

 

Broader impacts: We used our tools to provide estimates of extinction risk due to overfishing for shark and ray species that were proposed for listing under Appendix II at the 2019 and 2022 Convention of Parties for CITES.  In support of this goal, we compiled existing datasets on sharks and rays and developed an open access dataset on traits - such as generation time and number of offspring - that is now a resource for the global conservation community (www.sharkipedia.org). We conducted workshops to train students to use the cutting-edge modeling tools we used and developed. We also trained a student from Ecuador in the methods used to analyze the fisheries for groupers. These efforts complemented the mentoring and training of four early career researchers in fisheries science.
